title: Markets turn sour on eurozone as economic activity shrinks
text:

Latest news

For up-to-the-minute coronavirus updates visit our live blog

  • Sales of previously owned homes in the US hit a 14-year high in 2020, as low borrowing costs and the shift to working from home boosted demand during the pandemic

  • An FT analysis showed assets in emerging markets have attracted $17bn of inflows in the first three weeks of 2021 thanks to central bank stimulus

  • The UK's financial regulator has given insurance companies a week to write to customers to tell them if their claims will be affected by a court ruling on business interruption policies

ECB details strategy shift as fears grow of double-dip recession

Investors took fright today at a key survey suggesting that tighter coronavirus lockdowns were increasing the likelihood of a double-dip recession in the eurozone.

Early readings of IHS Markit's purchasing managers' index showed a fall of 1.6 points to 47.5 in January — the third consecutive month below the 50 mark that indicates a shrinking in business activity.

“Growth, which was widely anticipated for 2021, has essentially been pushed back to later in the year,” explained one portfolio manager.

The bloc's services sector has been hit particularly hard by lockdowns, strengthened in recent weeks in countries including Germany and the Netherlands, in the face of a resurgent virus. Manufacturers, by contrast, managed to retain some sense of optimism, although developing problems include a large jump in input costs because of shipping problems between Asia and Europe.

The European Central Bank yesterday unveiled its latest measures to tackle the crisis with a shift in its bond-buying strategy as it left interest rates and its main stimulus package unchanged. Its description of a new “holistic and multi-faceted approach” foxed some analysts. “Why make it so complicated? Constructive ambiguity can be a good thing, until it is no longer constructive,” commented one strategist.

There was no ambiguity, however, over the continuing threat from the virus as European leaders met virtually to discuss developments including the tightening of travel restrictions.

As our Brussels Briefing newsletter reports, they are reluctant to close borders within the free movement zone — comprising the EU27 plus Norway, Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Iceland — but are considering toughening quarantines and testing, border checks and access from third countries. France said all visitors would now need to have passed a Covid-19 test less than three days before entering.

Vaccines are also the subject of intense debate across the bloc. AstraZeneca warned today  that it would fail to meet delivery timetables for its jab, while Brussels is fighting back moves from Austria, the Czech Republic, Denmark and Greece for it to be delivered before final authorisation from the EU medical regulator.  Member states and the European Commission are also talking  to pharma companies about how many shots can be extracted from individual capsules of vaccine. There is also discussion of proposals from Greece for a “vaccine passport” to make travel around the EU easier.

Markets

Value investing guru Seth Klarman said US Federal Reserve decisions to cut interest rates to record low levels and flood the financial system with money had made it difficult to judge the health of the country's economy. “As with frogs in water that is slowly being heated to a boil, investors are being conditioned not to recognise the danger,” he wrote in the FT.

The pandemic is forcing savers to switch to online platforms, in turn leading advisers to speed up their use of new technology, veteran investment funds chief Edward Bonham Carter told the FT. The crisis has brought to the fore longstanding investor concerns about fees and complex charging structures.

Personal finance columnist Merryn Somerset Webb argues that a new wave of US fiscal stimulus may well lead to improved growth but will almost certainly result in rising inflation.

Business

The prices of hundreds of essential pandemic products have shot up on Amazon during the crisis. Most — but not all — were being sold by third-party sellers — but the company said the data failed to compare its prices with competitors such as Walmart and factor in increased storage costs or supply chain constraints.

Some large companies in the UK have complained that they have been left out of coronavirus support schemes because the government is sticking to EU state-aid rules — even though the country has now left the bloc.

The global healthcare industry is preparing for a permawar on Covid, says companies editor Tom Braithwaite. Britain's vaccination efforts are being helped by Wockhardt, a once high-flying Indian pharma company that has been investigated by US regulators in the past for failings at its plants.

Global economy

US House Democrats said they stood ready to pass President Joe Biden's $1.9tn coronavirus relief bill by February 1 as new jobless claims highlighted the economic cost of the pandemic which, the president warned, could result in the country's death toll passing 500,000 next month. New initiatives announced by the Biden administration this week include the use of wartime powers to boost production of medical supplies and joining the World Health Organization's Covax project to secure vaccine supplies for poorer countries.

Japan insisted the delayed 2020 Olympics would go ahead this summer, even as the country's borders remained closed and Tokyo was in a state of coronavirus emergency. Vaccines are not an issue: organisers do not believe national immunisation campaigns will reach healthy young athletes by the summer. National Olympic committees around the world need to make financial commitments to attend by the end of March.

A gloomy suite of data highlighted the parlous state of the UK economy ahead of the country's Budget next month. Economic activity is at its lowest since May; consumer spending fell sharply in early January; there was little Christmas cheer for retailers; and the public finances continued to deteriorate. Ministers, meanwhile, are discussing increased support for workers forced to self-isolate.

Have your say

Kool with a K comments on Small UK businesses are ‘running out of cash', chancellor warned:

“I've worked in the SME sector and the corporate sector. SME owners are the lifeblood of the economy and this is depressing on so many levels. If it was corporates who were suffering I wouldn't really care all that much, but to see people remortgaging their homes to keep the companies they've spent their lives building, well it's all incredibly sad.”
